summary: Howard H. Baker, Jr. is mentioned in the context of Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities (SSC) investigations during the 1970s. While the documents do not explicitly detail Baker's direct involvement, they highlight the SSC's inquiries into various intelligence matters, including the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., as well as related activities of the FBI and CIA. The documents reflect the SSC's efforts to gather information and materials from agencies like the FBI and NSA, indicating Baker's potential oversight role as a member or leader within the committee during these investigations.
key_connections: Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities (SSC)
significance: Howard H. Baker, Jr.'s significance in the JFK context stems from his association with the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities (SSC) during its investigation into intelligence matters, including the JFK assassination. While the documents don't provide specifics on his individual contributions, his presence within the SSC suggests a role in overseeing or participating in the committee's inquiries and access to relevant information.
